lens.book_chapters: Part 1: The Cold Start Problem and Atomic Networks.

reinforcements.similarity: Both reduce user-side translation labor by converting ambiguous market signals into immediately usable decisions.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Inside-out evidence shows users fail when forced to translate platform formats (works-006). Outside-in evidence shows Roomi users manually infer local viability and churn when liquidity is opaque (disappoint-001/002, opp-002). Together, they support explicit matchability translation as a core pattern.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The same cognitive-friction mechanism appears in direct user cognition data and competitor failure analysis, indicating a durable cross-context need.

reinforcements.similarity: Both prioritize legible, decision-ready financial and viability summaries before detailed breakdowns.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack calls validate single-sum comprehension as the fastest trust-preserving financial format. Reverse-benchmark transcripts add uncertainty around pricing/search clarity and local depth. Combined, they justify a first-screen summary model for both money and liquidity.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Independent host-call and competitor-user language converge on the same requirement: one clear headline metric before complexity.

reinforcements.similarity: Both preserve conversational speed while structuring high-stakes decisions.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-003 shows the platform must match the speed of human conversation to avoid abandonment. Reverse-benchmark evidence shows commitment steps leaking to text and ad hoc interviews (disappoint-004, crossref on off-platform texting). Together they support an in-thread structured terms rail.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The speed requirement is now validated against two benchmarks: trusted calls and real competitor workaround behavior.

reinforcements.similarity: Both make trust continuity explicit at the point where users otherwise re-open legitimacy checks.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-004 shows trust transfer fails when digital surfaces do not carry human continuity. Reverse-benchmark calls repeatedly ask for legitimacy proof and background checks before commitment. Combined evidence favors explicit trust scaffolding embedded in negotiation mechanics.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: The trust gap is corroborated by both first-party host psychology and competitor-side fraud/legitimacy anxiety language.

reinforcements.similarity: Both convert proposal handling from open-ended construction into guided, low-latency confirmation flow.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: communicates-005 establishes pre-packaged proposal confirmation as the low-effort default. Reverse-benchmark evidence identifies ghosting and response latency as conversion killers in first 48 hours (disappoint-005). Combined, they support protocolized prompt/milestone choreography in proposal messaging.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Both process lenses independently identify the same conversion bottleneck: unstructured early negotiation.

extensions.gap_filled: Adds post-stay portable roommate reputation as a persistent trust-memory layer across cycles and cities.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence: strategically coherent and strongly supported by competitor trust-reset patterns, but still lighter on direct in-product behavioral evidence than design-stack call-grounded elements.

extensions.gap_filled: Extends pre-signup discovery with neighborhood-time atomic liquidity proof and response forecasting.
extensions.confidence_note: Moderate confidence: strong Cold Start fit and repeated outside-in complaints about opacity, with limited direct inside-out measurement of pre-signup drop causes.

extensions.gap_filled: Introduces explicit 48-hour bilateral response SLAs as a first-class interaction protocol.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence: transcript crossrefs repeatedly cite timing fragility and off-platform nudging, though exact SLA thresholds need empirical tuning.

cross_process_insights.insight: Trust is not a badge problem; it is a conversion-timing problem that peaks before and during commitment.
cross_process_insights.implication: Prioritize trust mechanisms that are embedded in flow state and timing (verification + guided terms + response protocol), not standalone profile decoration.

cross_process_insights.insight: Users consistently need one primary decision number/signal before they can process details.
cross_process_insights.implication: Adopt a universal information hierarchy rule: headline viability/cost metric first, conversion and breakdown second, deep detail on demand.

cross_process_insights.insight: Network effects in this category fail mainly through lifecycle truncation, not acquisition scarcity alone.
cross_process_insights.implication: To compound defensibility, design must capture active-stay and post-stay behavior as reusable trust capital rather than ending at match creation.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a guest-side lifecycle study focused on post-stay behavior capture and what users would accept as fair, portable roommate reputation evidence.
next_run_recommendations.reason: rb-roomi-ui-004 is the highest-moat extension but currently depends more on outside-in inference than direct inside-out behavioral proof.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Benchmark competitors with explicit commitment rails (terms capture, response SLAs, in-flow acceptance) to identify operational patterns Split Lease can adopt faster.
next_run_recommendations.reason: Cross-process agreement is strongest at commitment and communication bottlenecks, where implementation details now matter more than problem validation.
